review_title: Impressive, but not for the reasons mentioned by the people from it's country of origin...
review_detailed_main: If you remove it's impressive visuals, "Bãhubali" at first isn't so different from your typical blockbuster from India. As always, there are a lot of scenes that will destroy your brain cells with how over the top and stupid they are, but let's be real, you wouldn't be watching this if you weren't expecting that. The thing that elevates "Bãhubali" above the rest of India's blockbusters is the fact that it feels like a story written by a kid who is hardcore into heroic fantasy. How is that different from the rest of the movies from India you ask? Well, because this story is somehow actually cool despite being written by a kid! And so, while I was watching the movie, despite my brain screaming from pain this Tollywood absurdity has been putting me through, the kid in me was in awe how cool it feels at the same time. It's hard to explain, but somehow, with it's style and approach to editing "Bãhubali" manages to keep you entertained and interested during it's two and a half hours runtime. And, honestly, I really don't expect nor want much more from a movie like this. Therefore, I recommend it to everyone! Turn off your brain and let the kid inside you watch and enjoy itself. 8/10!

Baahubali Baahubali - The Beginning is a film co-written and directed by S S Rajamouli. As I remember watching the trailer about 3 years ago, I could go on praising the grandeur of the film. And I watched the film back then and couldn't stop praising it. Watching it again after a long time, made me feel nostalgic.

Plot: Shivudu's life changes after he meets Avanthika

Story and direction: I still don't think that there is nothing that is quite great with the story. It is a mishmash of Ramayana and Mahabharata. Anyone watching it will know what I am talking about. But the way S S Rajamouli has taken what we know and incorporated into the world of Mahismati is incredible. The story also doesn't provide you all the information at once. It keeps the mystery so that the audience stay intrigued and interested. You can see the hard work that has gone into the making of this magnum-opus. I can go on praising the Mahismati kingdom. The characters are also varied and interesting. You can care for each character that is in the film. The stunt sequences are also great and look very much real (quite rare in South Indian cinema). But everything has faults and so does this one. I felt the romantic track was added just to bring the audience to the theatres. It just added to the runtime and nothing substantial was there in that. Also the VFX was OK. In some scenes, you can just guess that green/blue screen was used. Also the editing is not crisp. Characters happen to just pop up at some places. Some scenes also never made sense.

Performances: Prabhas stole the show. His dual roles as Babhubali and Shivudu were impressive. Rana Daggubati was great too. The stern and angered looks were nicely carried by him. Sathyaraj was impressive as Katappa. Nassar looked cruel as Bijjalaeva. Ramya Krishnan was beyond praise as Sivagami. Tamannah Bhatia was eye-candy for me. Anushka Shetty was also good in the role provided.

Music: Very rarely I do love South Indian music. M M Keeravani delivers some great songs and an impressive background score. Although I liked each and every song of the film, 'Dheevera' was the one that impressed me the most.

Favorite Scene: The scene just before the interval where Shivudu helps in the installation of the golden statue of Bhallaladeva. When one person happens to see Shivudu and says 'Baahubali' and everyone just repeat the same, the energy they get helps in the installation of the statue. The sheer grandness and respect for Baahubali the people have inspired me a lot.

Verdict: Even with its faults and some stupidity, Baahubali is an enjoyable experience. I was never bored even for a milli-second.

I am going with an 8/10.

I learnt about this movie through memes and social media blogs. I didn't have a TV connection back then and I wasn't much into pop culture, so I didn't really know what this movie was about. I just saw that this movie had a lot of special effects and it used animators, so obviously it had to be good. I practically begged my parents to let me see this movie in the theatres. I hadn't been to the theatres for the last 7 years, and they finally gave me the permission to see this one. And I wasn't disappointed.

This is the kind of movie that can be enjoyed to its fullest only in the theatres. Everything about it was superb - the CGI (considering the technology and experience of CGI in India is not very advanced), the acting, the music, the colour palette, the locations, the overall tone, everything is perfect. Watching Shiva climb the waterfalls, the battle scenes, Shiva alone pulling Bhallaldeva's statue, all of this looked great when being watched on a giant screen.

The story finally ended on a cliffhanger for the second part, which is another movie for which I requested my parents to let me see, but that's for the other review. But it was an actual good cliffhanger, unlike the usual sequel baiters that we normally see in high budget action or superhero movies, or the money squeezing that happens when one movie becomes successful. This one actually meant it.

This movie basically introduced me to South Indian cinema. Until then I was thinking all South Indian movies are the same, with unrealistic actions and cringy humour. But this one was different. Just by looking at it you know this one really means business. I hope in future we will get to see more such Indian movies that make us proud that we have a film industry that prioritises quality over quantity.

Baahubali, directed by S. S. Rajamouli, is a groundbreaking achievement in Indian cinema. Spanning two parts, this epic saga blends myth, fantasy, and historical drama, setting new benchmarks in storytelling and visual effects. The story of two cousins, Amarendra Baahubali and Bhallaladeva, vying for the throne of Mahishmati, is compelling and filled with twists. The stunning visuals, powerful performances, and intricate narrative make "Baahubali" an unforgettable experience, redefining Indian cinema's standards and captivating audiences worldwide. Its grandeur and emotional depth ensure it remains a must-watch.

review_title: So bad it's good, until it becomes boring.
review_detailed_main:
I didn't finish it, I just couldn't. I don't understand how this movie can even be compared to Lord of the Rings or 300.

"Try hard" is the best way I can describe this movie. It's like if you see an experience martial artist do a Kata and you try to copy the movement without understanding what a Kata is. You may think your movement was identical, but those who know about martial art will see the flaws. It's exactly what this movie is doing, it tries to be that epic breath taking movie, but don't understand what made those movie epic in the first place. So we end up with our over the top hero who "tries hard" to be badass, but end up being laughable instead, serious scene who "tries hard" to be sad and dramatic, but falls into the melodramatic and end us making us laugh.

You may say it's a matter of taste, but even on a technical level the movie fails. To make a good slow motion you have to film it at a higher frame rate. Because there is more frame per seconds, when you slow it down, you end up with a crystal clear slow motion. In other word, slow motion scenes need to be carefully planned. That's not what this movie is doing and what result of it is a tacky and blurry looking scene. Also balance...if you try to make every little action look epic...nothing end up looking epic.

It's sad this movie could have had some potential (which is why I gave it 2 stars instead of one.), some scenes do look good and the actors aren't that bad. Its a shame their acting is ruined by over dramatic (to not say parodic) camera shots and bad directing.

Direction and Production. S. S. Rajamouli is at his best,the way he has handled the film is commendable. The effort put in by him and his team shows clearly in every frame of the film. The detailing of each aspect of the film,be it the costumes,weaponry,sets especially the grandeur of Mahamishti Kingdom make this film a visual spectacle. The VFX is outstanding,never seen before in Indian Cinema and it wont be wrong to say that they match up to Hollywood standards. Two scenes that that will simply take your breath away are;the waterfall climbing and the war sequences. I can vouch that these are the most well crafted scenes in Indian Cinema.

Acting. Prabhas plays the double role of Sivudu/Baahubali. He has pulled off both the roles with great ease. This is the best performance of his career till date. Rana Daggubatti is menacing as the villain Bhallala Dev. Ramya is brilliant. Sudeep has a small role but he plays his part with perfection. The rest of the cast overacts which is a big letdown.

Music The background is the best one which I have ever heard. M. M. Kreem's soundtrack is a brilliant. All the songs compliment the story and are well written.

Verdict. I go 9/10 for this marvel. The film is way ahead from the ones made in bollywood and will surely bring Indian Cinema into the big league.
SS Rajamouli's imagination is just marvellous.. Prabhas dedication, Anushka acting.. Rana villainism and Keeravani Music is really very great..

The Baahubali movies are a cinematic triumph, combining mythology, drama, and action in a way that captivates audiences. They stand as a testament to the power of visionary filmmaking and have earned a place in the annals of Indian film history. Whether for its performances, visual effects, or storytelling, Baahubali is a must-watch for any cinema lover.

The Baahubali series, with its compelling storyline and larger-than-life characters, stands out as a modern epic in Indian cinema, offering a blend of emotion, drama, and visual grandeur.

Key Themes and Elements: Heroism and Legacy: The story emphasizes the virtues of bravery, loyalty, and the enduring legacy of heroism passed from father to son.

Betrayal and Redemption: The narrative is driven by themes of betrayal and redemption, particularly in the relationships between Sivagami, Kattappa, and Baahubali.

Epic Battles and Spectacle: The series is known for its grand battle sequences and visual spectacle, blending mythological elements with high-stakes action.

Strong Characters: Each character, from the noble Baahubali to the fierce Devasena, plays a crucial role in the unfolding drama.

"Baahubali: The Beginning" and its sequel "Baahubali 2: The Conclusion" stand as towering monuments in the realm of Indian cinema. Directed by S. S. Rajamouli, these epic films have not only redefined the boundaries of Indian filmmaking but have also captivated audiences worldwide with their grandeur, storytelling, and visual splendor.

From the very first frame, "Baahubali: The Beginning" immerses viewers into a mesmerizing world filled with rich mythology, breathtaking landscapes, and larger-than-life characters. The film follows the journey of Shivudu, a young man with humble beginnings, as he discovers his royal lineage and embarks on a quest to reclaim his rightful throne.

One of the most striking aspects of "Baahubali" is its unparalleled visual spectacle. Every frame is meticulously crafted, showcasing stunning sets, intricate costumes, and awe-inspiring visual effects that transport the audience to the mythical kingdom of Mahishmati. Whether it's the breathtaking waterfall sequence or the epic battle scenes, the film's visuals are nothing short of cinematic poetry.

At the heart of "Baahubali" lies a timeless tale of love, betrayal, and redemption. The film masterfully weaves together elements of drama, romance, and action, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats throughout its runtime. The chemistry between the characters, particularly the bond between Shivudu and Avanthika, adds depth and emotional resonance to the narrative, making it more than just a spectacle but a compelling human drama.

Rajamouli's direction is nothing short of genius, as he seamlessly blends larger-than-life action sequences with intimate character moments. Each character is given their moment to shine, from the valiant Baahubali to the cunning Bhallaladeva, creating a rich tapestry of personalities that drive the story forward. The performances, led by Prabhas, Rana Daggubati, and Anushka Shetty, are top-notch, with each actor fully embodying their respective roles and bringing them to life with nuance and depth.

Apart from its technical brilliance and compelling narrative, "Baahubali" also serves as a celebration of Indian culture and heritage. From its epic battle sequences inspired by ancient Indian warfare to its portrayal of familial bonds and honor, the film pays homage to the rich tapestry of Indian mythology and history. It's a reminder of the power of storytelling to unite people across cultures and generations, resonating with audiences far beyond the borders of India.

The success of "Baahubali" also paved the way for Indian cinema to reach new heights on the global stage. With its record-breaking box office performance and critical acclaim, the film shattered stereotypes and proved that Indian filmmakers are capable of producing world-class cinema that can compete with the best of Hollywood. Its success opened doors for Indian actors, directors, and technicians to showcase their talent on a global platform, earning the respect and admiration of audiences worldwide.

In conclusion, "Baahubali" is not just a film; it's a cinematic masterpiece that transcends boundaries and generations. With its epic storytelling, breathtaking visuals, and powerful performances, it has rightfully earned its place in the annals of cinema history. Whether you're a fan of action, drama, or romance, "Baahubali" has something for everyone, making it a must-watch for film enthusiasts everywhere.

review_title: Biggest Motion Picture in India-Best in Everything
review_detailed_main: Longest pre-production. Massive budget and huge star cast. Thousands of sketches. And much more. This is possible only when you have SS Rajamouli onboard. Though the film has a routine content, the VFX and CG works make it unique among all the Indian films and pushes it towards the top spot in everything. The actors are terrific, the technicians are terrific - everything is terrific. The songs are picturised well. Tightly engaging screenplay. The direction is fantastic. BGM elevates the scene and creates a mood. Costumes are amazing. All the actors performed well. You cannot judge a film like this, since it is new to this generation.

"Baahubali: The Beginning" is an epic Indian film directed by S. S. Rajamouli that swept audiences off their feet with its grandeur, breathtaking visuals, and compelling storytelling........ this magnum opus captivated me with my family with its larger-than-life characters, stunning cinematography, and a storyline steeped in intrigue, revenge, and royal lineage...... The film transports audiences to the ancient Kingdom of Mahishmati, where the narrative unfolds around a gripping tale of power, betrayal, and destiny. The plot revolves around Prabhas the main lead, a young man with a mysterious past, who discovers his true heritage and sets out on a quest to uncover the secrets surrounding his lineage......From majestic palaces to sprawling landscapes, the attention to detail in the film's visual presentation is nothing short of breathtaking. The action sequences, in particular, are spectacularly choreographed, showcasing gravity-defying stunts and battles on an epic scale.... "Baahubali: The Beginning" stands as a testament to Indian cinema's ability to create visually stunning and emotionally captivating storytelling. It's a cinematic spectacle that not only entertained audiences but also raised the bar for epic filmmaking in the Indian film industry.

Bahubali review :

Bedazzled by the near 3 hour extravaganza scripted and directed by Telugu whiz kid S. S. Rajamouli, I sit down now to write about my movie "experience". Yes, Bahubali is not just a film, it's an expeirence; a triumph of Rajamouli's vision and innovation. It is actually a 5+ hour spectacle out of which we get to see only the first part as 'Bahubali:The Beginning'.

Rajamouli takes the story outline from Disney 's 'Lion King', indianises it with characters inspired from Mahabharata ( the epic not the TV series) and presents it on a lavish scale in league of 'Lord of the Rings' and '300' series. The end result is a magnum opus never seen before in Indian cinema.

Technically, the movie is outstanding and every money spent (It's said to be most expensive Indian film) on the mind blowing CGI and VFX reflects on screen. The last hour war sequence matches the grandeur of '300' with possibly just a tenth of that movie's budget. Content wise too, the film connects with its audience and quite a few scenes stand out. The opening waterfall scene, the titular hero (Prabhas) lifting the Shiva linga, the antagonist's entry are imaginatively executed. On flip side, the romantic angle in first half appears distracting. Also, an item song post interval looks forced and needless.

Prabhas and Rana Daggubatti have worked hard on their physique and the effort is evident in their action scenes. Tamannah Bhatia looks pretty and acts better than her Sajid Khan outings in Hindi. Ramya Krishnan and Nasser lend good support.

After watching 'Eega' three years ago, I was eagerly awaiting Rajamouli's next. 'Bahubali :The Conclusion' is still a year away. Please bring it earlier, if possible....

Regards, Sumeet Nadkarni.

A visual treat.

If a person is bit of into movies, I am sure that person heard about Baahubali couple of years back. It took almost four years to complete the first part. Hero Prabhas had completely dedicated his time to this movie and no movie after his super successful movie Mirchi. Same is true from S. S Rajamouly, after his last non-conventional movie Eega. So obviously there are high expectations 3 years of sheer hard-work of many people who have worked their hearts out for this Visual Wonder has paid off well? Not exactly though, since the answer is simple and straight, you just have to wait for the 'Conclusion' till 2016 and that would decide the fate of this franchise on a whole. The story is paced slowly in the first half giving way and screen space to our Mother Nature's beauty and CGI's magic and one might find it a little too draggy if one considers 'Baahubali' to solely be a hero and since that's not possible, Shivudu has a love life and heroic nature and scenes of his own. Abrupt cuts and unconvincing CGI at certain places in first half are the only flaws with the whole film. Coming to the second half, one is told what he'd expect to be told, as the trailer tells the same. War sequences are really well shot and makes it hard to believe that they were actually made by Indians! One has to just bow down to Srinivas Mohan and his team for excellent CGI and Senthil Kumar for superb visuals. As it turns out, it is everything I expected it to be -- mega, ingenious and envelope pushing. There's never a dull moment in this 160-minutes long epic fantasy about a lost prince, rebellion, revenge, rivalry and a shocking betrayal to seize the throne, Our captain gives us a bang, as his trademark style known as 'Interval Bang' only at the end this time because technically this movies' end is the interval for the 2 parts taken as a whole. Art work in this Epic is just out of the world, kudos to Sabu Cyril sir and thousands of technicians who worked on this aspect. BGM is soothing for the first half which is apt for what we get on screen and the second half war episodes get the best of the lot BGMs to elevate the scenes. Songs are places really well except for 'Manohari' song. Dolby Atmos effect is an added attraction and I highly recommend people to watch this flick in theatres with this specific sound system, it will surely remain as a great experience for you. The sound effects are haunting, pleasing and give you goosebumps at the same time. Anushka had an extended cameo but did perform commendably well, special applause to her expressions. Special mention to Ramya Krishna madame, she was at her best! Katappa will blow your mind with his characteristics and Sathya Raj Sir does 100% justice to it. Though Prabhas and Rana Daggubati did well only their attitude in their respective roles stands out as the best because more of them is yet to come in the sequel. All you need to do is to watch the movie as it comes because expectations lead to disappointment. If you miss this movie, you've just lost a once in life-time 'Indian' movie experience on a big screen, Please do not add this movie into South Indian movie list. It is an Indian movie that stands on the top of the list. According to the story line everybody did their job well. I have to appreciate Rajamouli for his daring and dashing guts for doing a project like this one. He has set a new trend by directing this movie!

Mahendra Baahubali... Wow. This movie is amazing. Graphically thanks to AMD probably but S. S. Rajamouli made it a king of bollywood. This story will leave you at the edge of your seat and the characters are amazing as well as comically amusing. 10/10 throughout and loved every second of it.

Gave him 10 stars , although , if it was american i would mybe gave him less cos it is not polished as their movies , but as Indian movies , i expected some errors,and its great! ! So it deserve 10!

I really liked it , Watched it with family , we really enjoyed. Entire movie in a way entangles you into story and you all the time expect what will happen next. Worth watching , and if you can bear some west - east differences in story telling , you will really like this! Still need to watch 2nd part :)

Epic... Humongous... Stunning... This are one of the first words comes to mind when watching this magnificent film. It raises the bar to new pinnacle for Indian Cinema. It can easily compete with epic Hollywood movies like Troy, Gladiator etc. Dazzling visuals, good music and delightfully crafted final battle are few of the strong points of the movie along with its well-built fascinating story which never became stale. And cliffhanger at the end keep me waiting impatiently for the Conclusion.

Direction, acting everything nicely complement each other. Leading actors Prabhas and Rana had done lots of hard work which pays off marvelously. They totally own the characters and do that effortlessly. Ramya Krishnan, Satyaraj are heart of the movie. Anushka Shetty is impressive and Tammana looks gorgeous. As a fan of epic movies LOTR, and TV series like GOT and Spartacus it's good to see our very own movie which excel like those. This movie brings new hope that someday we can finally see the adaptations of epic Mahabharata and Ramayana on silver screen which surely will make LOTR run for many... :)

I'm not a big fan of Bollywood movies and after having this recommended by a friend I have to hold my hands up and say this is darn good. Why this Movie has got so many negative reviews is beyond me because it definitely doesn't deserve them. If you're a fan of cinema give this a go I don't think you will be disappointed.

"Bahubali: The Beginning" is a cinematic masterpiece that redefines the epic genre in Indian cinema. The film boasts stunning visuals, grand sets, and breathtaking action sequences. S. S. Rajamouli's direction is impeccable, blending mythology and history seamlessly. Prabhas and Rana Daggubati deliver powerful performances, bringing their characters to life with intensity and charisma. M. M. Keeravani's music and the outstanding VFX elevate the storytelling to new heights. The intricate plot, rich with emotion and drama, keeps viewers captivated throughout. "Bahubali: The Beginning" is a monumental achievement, setting a new benchmark for epic storytelling.

This movie was a quantum-leap in terms of indigenous VFX and grand story telling. It generated pan-India appeal and rooted in Indianness as opposed to the popular Bollywood movies which has a lot of global influence and is usually preachy in it's undertones.

If you are new to Indian cinema and looking for a package of action, drama, romance, value system etc. This would be a great start.

review_title: a must watch fantasy movie..... breath taking that will force u to stand on your feet after it ends

review_detailed_main:
Not being all that familiar with Indian cinema or pop culture, I really didn't know what to expect when I added this to my Netflix queue, just that it looked colorful and might be entertaining. Being not all that fond of musicals, I almost bugged out of the movie about fifteen or twenty minutes in.

But something made me stick with it, and I'm glad I did.

Take one part "Machiste" muscleman sword-and-sandal flick, one part "Lord of the Rings", add a liberal dose of Shakespearean tragedy, and season the result a bit too heavily (for my taste, anyway) with lavish musical numbers (Okay, I did like the Mahishmati anthem: It's a stirring and very catchy composition.) Garnish with some jaw-dropping wackiness -- from a Western perspective, anyway -- and you've got "Baahubali".

I have to admit I found the second movie somewhat better than the first, but by the end of "Baahubali: The Beginning" I was captivated by its larger-than-life characters and epic storytelling. This and its sequel are well worth watching, even if like me you're not a big fan of Bollywood films.

review_title: Bollywood marks new heights with this
review_detailed_main: This comes with a bang into the Indian cinema and sets a benchmark for other Bollywood movies. A wonderful fantasy tale with trendsetting screenplay. The visuals, the dialogues are worth watching multiple times. Prabhas adds new life to Bollywood with his powerful screenplay and so do Ramya and Rana. From the action to the sensual dance to the plot this movie does well in all respect. Rajamouli does a marvel job with the brilliant imagination and execution. Hope to see movies of this class again and again. These movies are one that can make one proud to be an Indian and thing to boast off.
A great movie with a great story and amazing visuals. Alltime favourite.
